topic.title: AI Positron for Web Author VPAT Accessibility Conformance Report

section.title: International Edition
section.p:
VPAT® Version 2.5Rev – April 2025
Name of Product/Version
Product Description plugin provides the ability to use a specific AI engine (OpenAI, Microsoft Azure OpenAI, or Anthropic Claude) for chat purposes or to run useful predefined actions.
Report Date October 2025
Contact Information support@oxygenxml.com
Notes has been designed and enhanced to adhere to the U.S. Government Section 508 accessibility standards and the Web Content Accessibility Guidelines (WCAG). For details, see .
Evaluation Methods Used:
The following applications were used for testing :
Desktop browsers: Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge.
Assistive technologies: NVDA, VoiceOver, JAWS, Microsoft Narrator.

section.title: Applicable Standards/Guidelines
section.p: This report covers the degree of conformance for the following accessibility standards/guidelines:

row.entry:
Level A - Yes
Level AA - Yes
Level AAA - No

Level A - Yes
Level AA - Yes
Level AAA - No

p.xref: Revised Section 508 standards published January 18, 2017 and corrected January 22, 2018

row.entry: EN 301 549 Accessibility requirements suitable for public procurement of ICT products and services in Europe, - V3.1.1 (2019-11)

section.title: Terms
section.p: The terms used in the Conformance Level information are defined as follows:

ul.li: Supports: The functionality of the product has at least one method that meets the criterion without known defects or meets with equivalent facilitation.
Partially Supports: Some functionality of the product does not meet the criterion.
Does Not Support: The majority of product functionality does not meet the criterion.
Not Applicable: The criterion is not relevant to the product.
Not Evaluated: The product has not been evaluated against the criterion. This can be used only in WCAG 2.0 Level AAA.

section.title: WCAG 2.x Report
section.p:
Tables 1 and 2 also document conformance with Revised Section 508:
Chapter 5 – 501.1 Scope, 504.2 Content Creation or Editing
Chapter 6 – 602.3 Electronic Support Documentation

p.note: This report follows the WCAG 2.2 Conformance Requirements; the conformance model is that of WCAG 2.x; target conformance: Levels A and AA.

row.entry: The product provides text alternatives for non-text items.
The product does not provide prerecorded audio-only or video-only content.
The product does not provide prerecorded media that requires captions.

entry.p: 1.2.3 Audio Description or Media Alternative (Prerecorded) (Level A)

row.entry: The product does not provide prerecorded media that requires audio description.

Most user interface elements provide programmatic information about structure and relationships, except:
On the main panel, the action buttons are visually grouped but the group titles do not have heading semantics and are not announced by screen readers.
On the main panel, the action buttons are visually grouped, but this cannot be determined programmatically.
In the "Actions" checkbox, sub-headers are not programmatically associated with the buttons that follow in the list.
In the conversation panel between AI and user:
Messages and their associated actions are not linked programmatically.
Who speaks (user vs. AI) is not exposed programmatically.
The transcript is not live region (for example, new messages are not automatically announced).
The product presents content in a meaningful sequence.
The product does not rely on sensory characteristics of components such as shape, size, visual location, orientation, or sound for instructions.
The product functionality does not rely on color alone to convey information.
The product does not include audio that plays automatically.
The product functionality can be operated through a keyboard interface.
Visual elements can be traversed with the keyboard without getting stuck inside them.
The product does not have shortcuts mapped to only letter, punctuation, number or symbol characters.
The product does not include time limits.

entry.p: When a larger AI response is written, the text scrolls up.
However, if the user scrolls (for example, back) while generating larger content, the generation continues but the user can follow the content from where they scrolled without it escaping them.
2.3.1 Three Flashes or Below Threshold (Level A)

row.entry: The product does not contain content that flashes.

ul.li: 501 (Web)(Software) – Does not apply to non-web software
602.3 (Support Docs) – Does not apply to non-web docs

entry.p: The actions in the main panel cannot be bypassed when navigating with the keyboard. We have to visit them one by one.
However, if we access them from the actions menu we have the possibility to jump to the first / last one using the Home / End keys.

row.entry: The AI ​​Positron Assistant view has a title exposed as a tab label. This is announced by screen readers.
Components receive focus in a meaningful order.
The product has meaningful link phrases.
The product does not use multipoint or path-based gestures.
All interactions with the pointer are triggered on an up (click) event. There are no irreversible actions launched instantly, and the user has control over undoing or correcting actions.

For the action buttons on the main panel, as well as those in the “Actions” drop-down, the visible button text must be announced first by assistive technologies. Right now, an explanation of the button’s text is what is announced.
The product does not have any action that can be operated by device motion or user motion can also be operated.

entry.p: Responsibility is at the page level.
Oxygen Xml Web Author and Content Fusion set the lang attribute for the html element.

row.entry: Context changes do not occur when user interface components receive focus.
The product does not cause unexpected changes of context when interacting with elements.
The AI ​​Positron Assistant view does not include an action for accessing Help.

Screen readers do not announce why the Send button is disabled.
If text is entered in the search field in the Actions menu that does not match any action, screen readers do not announce "No actions found".

Labels are provided for input fields.
Exceptions:
Some text input fields only have placeholders.
The application does not contain repeatable multi-step processes.
The product does not have accessibility parsing errors.

entry.p: The product’s interface presents name, role and value information for controls in most cases.
The buttons: "New Chat", "History", "Favorites", "Attach project files", "Attach files from the local computer" are not properly announced by the screen readers (they just say "Button").

row.entry: The product does not provide live media that requires captions.
The product does not provide prerecorded video content that requires audio description.

The interface does not impose a fixed orientation and can be used in both modes (portrait/landscape). The layout and components resize dynamically.
However, compliance with the criterion is influenced by how it is respected in the parent application that includes the Positron view.
The producr does not collect user personal information; therefore, no input fields require programmatic identification of purpose.

entry.p: Most of the text meets the requirements.

ul.li: The placeholder in the AI ​​chat field uses a too light gray.

row.entry: In Actions panel, some user interface controls, such as the button labeled “Update Content Based on Images”, display truncated text (e.g., “Update Content Base...”) that cannot be fully viewed even when zoomed or when text size is increased to 200%. This results in loss of visible content and prevents users from understanding the complete label or function of the control.
The product does not contain images of text.
Most interface components scale correctly up to a zoom of 200%, but the conversation panel and action panel are not visible at zooms above 250%.

The product provides contrast for most active icons and indicators.
Exceptions:
"Actions" menu - search field & dividers: lines use very light gray on white background.
The separators that delimit the button panel at the top.
There is no loss of content or functionality in the editor when changing text spacing.

entry.p: 1.4.13 Content on Hover or Focus (Level AA 2.1 and 2.2)

row.entry: Content that appears on hover or focus is easy to read, maintain, and close.

ul.li: 501 (Web)(Software) – Does not apply to non-web software
602.3 (Support Docs) – Does not apply to non-web docs

row.entry: The buttons with the actions available for AI can be invoked both in the Actions Panel and from the Actions Menu.
Titles and labels in the interface clearly describe the subject or purpose of sections and controls.

entry.p: All focusable elements are highlighted when navigating using the keyboard.

ul.li: When focused via the keyboard, AI action buttons are only partially highlighted with a gray elliptical "background". For those with a longer label, the text extends outside the highlight.

entry.p: Generally, the elements that receive focus are fully visible at that moment.

ul.li: At 250% zoom, the Conversation Panel and Action Panel are not visible at all, and by default, neither are the buttons on them that receive focus when navigating with the keyboard.

row.entry: All dragging functionality provided by the application can be also performed without dragging.
Targets for pointer events are at least 24x24px in size.

The product interface and controls are consistently provided in English, and no language changes occur in menus or labels. However, when the AI translation or conversation feature displays generated text in other languages (e.g., French, German, Japanese), those content sections are not programmatically identified with the appropriate lang attribute.

ul.li: 501 (Web)(Software) – Does not apply to non-web software
602.3 (Support Docs) – Does not apply to non-web docs

row.entry: The product has a consistent navigation mechanism.

ul.li: 501 (Web)(Software) – Does not apply to non-web software
602.3 (Support Docs) – Does not apply to non-web docs

row.entry: There are no input fields with validation rules or detectable errors. The chat area does not involve human input checks that would trigger error messages or suggestions.
The product does not process legal commitments or financial transactions or modify user-controllable data.
The authentication process does not require cognitive function tests.
Screen readers do not announce the appearance of a new message from the AI ​​model.

entry.p: 1.4.7 Low or No Background Audio (Level AAA)
1.4.9 Images of Text (No Exception) Control (Level AAA)

row.entry: Much of the product is operable without vision; however. As noted in 1.3.1 Info and Relationships, some structural and hierarchical information is not communicated to screen reader users.

entry.p: The product provides several features that support users with limited vision, including clear visual layout, consistent navigation, and visible focus indicators. Text spacing and orientation adjustments are supported, and most interface elements maintain sufficient contrast.
However, some visual aspects reduce usability for users with low vision:

li.p: Certain text (e.g., placeholder text) does not meet minimum contrast requirements (WCAG 1.4.3).
When text size is increased or zoomed to 200% or more, some labels become truncated and panels are not fully visible (WCAG 1.4.4, 1.4.10).
A few non-text elements and focus indicators have insufficient contrast or partial highlighting (WCAG 1.4.11, 2.4.7).

row.entry: The product does not rely on color alone to convey information, status, or functionality
The product does not require hearing for use.
The product does not require hearing for use.
The product does not require speech for use.

The product can be fully operated using a keyboard without requiring fine motor control or simultaneous actions. It does not rely on complex pointer gestures, dragging movements, or motion-based input. Interactive elements generally meet the minimum target size and can be activated with standard keyboard or pointer controls.
The product does not require reach or strength for use.

entry.p: 302.9 With Limited Language, Cognitive, and Learning Abilities

row.entry:
The product provides a generally clear and consistent interface that can be understood and operated by users with limited language, cognitive, or learning abilities. However, several aspects reduce cognitive accessibility:
Some relationships and groupings between interface elements are not programmatically defined (see WCAG 1.3.1), which can make navigation and understanding of the UI structure more difficult.
Incomplete or truncated text at higher zoom levels (see WCAG 1.4.4, 1.4.10) can hinder comprehension.
Screen readers do not announce some dynamic updates or new messages (see WCAG 4.1.3), which can cause users to lose context during interactions.

section.title: Chapter 4: Hardware
section.p: Notes: Not Applicable - is not a hardware product.

section.title: Chapter 5: Software
section.p: Notes: is a web application, not a software product. However, the web application includes authoring functionality, hence Chapter 5: Software 504 Authoring Tools applies to this product.

row.entry: The product allows users to control most accessibility-related interactions (e.g., keyboard navigation, focus management) without requiring administrative privileges.
The software operates without disrupting the existing accessibility features of the system.
As noted in 1.3.1 Info and Relationships, some object information is not exposed programmatically.

entry.p: The product partially supports the requirement. Some user interface elements do not communicate changes in object information to assistive technologies.

li.p: Group titles and relationships between buttons and panels are not programmatically exposed (related to WCAG 1.3.1).
Several buttons (e.g., New Chat, Attach Files) are announced only as “Button” instead of exposing their accessible names, roles, and values (WCAG 4.1.2).
New messages in the AI conversation panel are not programmatically announced when they appear (WCAG 4.1.3).
Error states such as “No actions found” are not reported to screen readers (WCAG 3.3.1).

row.entry: The core product does not provide functionality to create or edit tables directly. However, tables may be displayed as part of AI chat responses. In such cases, the application relies on the underlying accessibility services to expose row, column, and header information where applicable.

Most user interface components expose their values through platform accessibility services. However, certain elements do not programmatically communicate their current values or changes. For example, in the conversation panel, new AI messages are not announced to assistive technologies, and the. Some grouped action buttons also lack programmatic value associations.
Values of controls can be set programmatically, including through assistive technology.

li.p: In the main panel, action buttons are visually grouped under headings, but those headings lack programmatic relationships and are not announced by assistive technologies.
In the “Actions” list, sub-headers are not programmatically associated with the buttons that follow them.
Some text input fields rely only on placeholder text, without proper label elements or accessible name attributes.
Certain buttons (e.g., “New Chat,” “History,” “Favorites,” “Attach project files”) are announced only as “button,” indicating missing or incorrect accessible names.
The conversation panel does not expose programmatic relationships between user and AI messages, meaning message ownership and grouping are not conveyed to screen readers.

entry.p: Most user interface elements expose their hierarchical relationships programmatically. However, some visual groupings are not programmatically associated:

li.p: On the main panel, action buttons are visually grouped, but the group titles are not exposed as headings or programmatically linked.
In the “Actions” panel, sub-headers are not associated with the following buttons.

row.entry: The product exposes most of the visible text content to accessibility services, allowing assistive technologies such as screen readers to announce textual information for interface elements, labels, and instructions.

entry.p: Newly generated AI responses in the conversation panel are not automatically announced, meaning dynamic text content is not exposed to accessibility APIs in real time.

row.entry: Actions that can be executed on an object can be determined programmatically from the actions panel and actions menu.
Actions on objects can performed by users, including those using assistive technologies.
The application exposes the focus location through the platform’s accessibility API. Screen readers correctly announce the focused element in all tested states.

entry.p: The product generally preserves the system-provided focus indicator and allows assistive technologies to track focus correctly. However, certain user interface elements reduce the clarity or visibility of the focus cursor:

li.p: Some action buttons display an incomplete focus highlight (the gray elliptical background does not fully cover the button text, particularly for longer labels).
At zoom levels of 250% or higher, parts of the interface (e.g., Conversation and Action Panels) may become obscured, preventing visible focus on the currently active element.

row.entry: In general, the product notifies assistive technologies of relevant user interface events. However, when typing in the Actions menu search field, if no matching actions are found, this status change is not announced by assistive technologies. As a result, screen reader users are not notified that the search returned no results.
This product is not platform software.
The product is a web application.
The product does not function as an assistive technology.

p.b: 503.4 User Controls for Captions and Audio Description

row.entry: The product does not provide controls for volume adjustment.
The product does not provide controls for program selection.

entry.p: 504.2 Content Creation or Editing (if not authoring tool, enter “not applicable”)
504.2.1 Preservation of Information Provided for Accessibility in Format Conversion

row.entry: The product does not provide format conversion.
The product does not provide PDF export.

The application provides features that encourage the inclusion of accessibility information — for example, a dedicated “Generate Image Alternate Text” action that prompts authors to add alternative text for images.
The product does provide several templates.

entry.p: 602.4 Alternate Formats for Non-Electronic Support Documentation
603.2 Information on Accessibility and Compatibility Features

section.title: Legal Disclaimer
section.p: This report describes Oxygen AI Positron Assistant Enterprise for Web Author's ability to support the stated VPAT Standards/Guidelines, subject to Syncro Soft's interpretation of the same. This accessibility report is provided for informational purposes only, and the contents hereof are subject to change without notice. SYNCRO SOFT MAKES NO WARRANTIES, EXPRESS OR IMPLIED, IN THIS DOCUMENT. For more information regarding the accessibility status, please contact us at sales@oxygenxml.com.
